yak-vybraty-hostyng.title: How to choose hosting for your business website
yak-vybraty-hostyng.excerpt: We go through the difference between shared hosting and VPS, what to look for in a plan and why the cheapest option can cost you customers.
body: Hosting is the foundation of any website. Even a perfect design and well-thought-out structure will not help if the site keeps going down or loads slowly. For a business, this means losing leads, trust and money.

The most common options are shared hosting and VPS. Shared works for small sites with low traffic, but you share resources with other clients. VPS provides more stability, flexibility and security, which is important for online stores and commercial projects.

When choosing hosting, pay attention to uptime (at least 99.5%), server response speed, support quality, backups and data center location. Good hosting combined with an optimized Next.js site gives fast page loads and better search rankings.
If you do not want to dig into technical details, I can help you choose the right plan and configure hosting for your project.

seo-dlya-lendingu.title: What is SEO for a landing page and where to start
seo-dlya-lendingu.excerpt: A simple explanation of how search engines see one-page sites, which sections matter for SEO and what you can improve without a big team.
body: Landing pages are often treated as purely advertising pages, but they can also bring organic traffic from search ‚Äì if you structure and write them correctly.

Key SEO elements for a landing page: one clear H1 with the main keyword, logical H2 headings for sections, optimized descriptions of services, fast load speed and responsiveness. Avoid a solid 'wall of text' ‚Äì it is better to break content into blocks and use bullet lists.

Do not forget about meta tags (title and description), structured data (schema.org), markup for contacts and clean URLs. All this helps search engines better understand what your landing is about and who it should be shown to.
I build landing pages with SEO in mind from day one: from structure and copy to technical optimization at the Next.js level.

react-vs-wordpress.title: Why I prefer React/Next.js over WordPress
react-vs-wordpress.excerpt: Comparing modern frontend stacks with classic CMS: performance, security, scalability and flexibility for business needs.
body: WordPress is a powerful CMS, but for modern projects developers increasingly choose React and Next.js. The main reasons are speed, flexibility and better control over the frontend.

Next.js combines server-side rendering, static page generation and client components. This means better SEO, faster loading and the ability to build complex interfaces without the limitations of themes and plugins.

WordPress is convenient for simple sites and blogs, but over time plugins can conflict, slow things down and create security issues. With React/Next.js you get a clean architecture, predictable code and the ability to scale the project without hacks.
I use Next.js where speed, unique UI, integrations and long-term project evolution matter. For simpler cases with a classic admin panel we can also combine it with a headless CMS.

core-web-vitals.title: Core Web Vitals: why website speed matters for SEO
core-web-vitals.excerpt: A clear explanation of LCP, CLS and INP and how they influence your rankings in Google.
body: Core Web Vitals is a set of metrics from Google that show how comfortable it is for users to interact with your website. They directly affect rankings, especially on mobile.

LCP (Largest Contentful Paint) measures how quickly the main content of the page loads. CLS (Cumulative Layout Shift) shows how much the layout shifts while loading. INP (Interaction to Next Paint) measures how fast the site reacts to user actions.
An optimized Next.js website with proper caching, lazy-loading for images and a minimal amount of render-blocking scripts can significantly improve Core Web Vitals without complex hacks.
When I build websites, I take performance into account from day one: page structure, image handling, fonts, caching. This way the site not only looks good but also ranks consistently well.

struktura-lendingu.title: Landing page structure that actually sells
struktura-lendingu.excerpt: Which sections every high-converting landing page should have so it not only looks nice but also brings leads.
body: An effective landing page is always about structure. In a few seconds the visitor should understand where they are, what you offer and why it is valuable.

The classic structure includes: a strong headline with a clear promise, a supporting subheadline, a benefits section, social proof (testimonials, case studies), a detailed description of the service or product, an FAQ block and a clear call-to-action.
Every section should support one goal ‚Äì getting the visitor to take action. Extra information, chaotic elements or weak CTAs reduce conversion, even if the design looks modern.
When I design landing pages, I help clients build this logic from the first screen to the order form so that marketing and design work together.

optimizaciya-shvydkosti.title: Speed optimization: making your site faster in practice
optimizaciya-shvydkosti.excerpt: What actually affects your website load speed and how to improve it quickly without a full redesign.
body: Page load speed is one of the key factors that affect both user experience and Google rankings. Every extra second of delay increases the percentage of visitors who simply close the page.

The most common issues are heavy unoptimized images, missing caching and unnecessary scripts and styles that block rendering. In practice you can fix this by compressing images, using modern formats (WebP), enabling a CDN and configuring cache properly.

Next.js gives you powerful tools for optimization: automatic code-splitting, the Image component, static generation and server-side rendering. The main thing is to set up the project correctly and not turn the page into a chaotic collection of third-party scripts.

When I work on websites, I always check Core Web Vitals and optimize critical resources so that pages load quickly even on mobile connections. If you want to check your current project, you can simply request an audit or development.

konversiya-lendingu.title: How to increase landing page conversion without more ad spend
konversiya-lendingu.excerpt: Which changes in structure, copy and design can bring more leads without increasing the advertising budget.
body: Most business owners try to solve a low number of leads by spending more on ads. But often it is more effective to first improve the landing page itself.

Start with the hero section: a clear headline with a value proposition, a supporting subheadline and a visible call-to-action button. Then build a logical structure of sections: benefits, social proof, detailed service description, answers to objections and only then the form.

Wording matters a lot: be specific instead of vague promises, focus on results for the client and use simple, clear CTAs like "Get a consultation" or "Calculate the price". To roughly estimate the budget right now, you can use the website cost calculator.

When I optimize landings for conversion, I analyze the user journey, remove unnecessary steps, improve readability and place accents where they really influence the decision to submit a request. If you want to review your landing in detail, just request a consultation.

bezpeka-saitu.title: Website security basics many businesses ignore
bezpeka-saitu.excerpt: Why SSL, updates and backups are not just a formality but a must for any business website.
body: Even a small corporate site can become a target for attacks: password brute-force, exploits in outdated plugins, spam bots in forms. The consequences are data loss, hosting suspension or being flagged as unsafe by browsers.
At minimum you should have: an SSL certificate, regular CMS and plugin updates, strong passwords with limited access and basic protection of forms from bots (reCAPTCHA or alternatives).
For custom Next.js projects it is also important to handle secrets correctly, avoid storing keys in public code and configure security headers and protection against XSS/CSRF attacks.
In my projects I follow modern security practices and recommend simple routines for clients: who has access, how often backups are made and what to do in case of an incident.

stvorennya-saitu-cina.title: How much does a website really cost: what affects the price
stvorennya-saitu-cina.excerpt: Breaking down what forms the cost of a website, why a proper landing page cannot cost like a coffee and which factors actually influence the budget.
body: When a business orders a website for the first time, the question "how much does it cost?" appears immediately. The generic answer "it depends" helps no one. In reality, the price of a website comes from several clear components: project type, design, functionality, integrations, content and ongoing support.

The cheapest option is a simple template-based landing page without complex features. Above that are custom-designed landings, corporate sites with multiple sections, blogs and online stores. More pages, integrations (CRM, payments, personal accounts) and custom components mean a higher budget.

The tech stack also affects the price. A site built with a modern framework like Next.js gives you better performance, SEO and scalability, but requires a more experienced developer than a drag-and-drop builder or a basic template.

To get a realistic estimate for your case, you can use the website cost calculator on this page or simply request a detailed consultation. I will help you choose a solution without overpaying and with room for future growth.

landing-chi-site.title: Landing page or multi-page website: what should your business choose
landing-chi-site.excerpt: Explaining when a one-page landing is enough and when it is better to invest in a full multi-page website with several sections and a blog.
body: A landing page is a focused page built around one main action: submit a request, buy a product, book a call. It is perfect for testing a niche, promoting a single service or running ad campaigns with a clear offer.

A multi-page website is needed when you have several directions, different audiences, content marketing (a blog), SEO for many queries and a more complex structure. Examples include studios with multiple services, manufacturing companies, educational projects or stores with a catalog.

If you are just starting and want to quickly validate demand, a well-designed single page is often enough. But if you already have an established business, several services, case studies, articles and long-term plans, it usually makes sense to invest into a full website from day one.

I help clients choose the right format during the briefing stage. After a short call we can understand whether a high-quality landing is enough or we should plan a multi-page structure. You can request a consultation, and we will pick the optimal format for your goals.

seo-pislya-zapusku.title: SEO after website launch: what to do next to get traffic
seo-pislya-zapusku.excerpt: The site is live ‚Äî what now? A checklist of actions that will help grow organic traffic instead of just waiting.
body: Many people think that once the site is launched, the main task is to turn on ads and wait for leads. But if you want stable organic traffic, you need to build an SEO routine from the start: analytics, content, links and technical health.

The first step is to connect analytics (Google Analytics or alternatives) and set up Google Search Console. There you will see how your site is indexed, which queries it appears for and which pages need attention.
The second step is a content plan. Regularly publishing helpful blog posts, updating key pages, improving copy and headings sends a strong signal that your website is alive and evolving.

The third step is technical health: performance (see the articles on Core Web Vitals and speed optimization), mobile friendliness, clean URLs and no critical errors. Together this defines whether your site will move up or slowly drop in search results.

If you want a specific action plan for your project, the easiest approach is to request a consultation. I will analyze your current site and suggest prioritized steps that will bring the biggest impact.

pomylky-pry-zamovlenni-saitu.title: Common mistakes when ordering a website: how not to ruin the project at the start
pomylky-pry-zamovlenni-saitu.excerpt: Typical decisions at the ordering stage that kill results: from saving on the wrong things to having no clear requirements.
body: One of the most common mistakes when ordering a website is to start with the question "how much does it cost?" without understanding why you need the site and what business problem it should solve. As a result the business gets a beautiful page with no leads, and the developer formally delivers on a weak specification.

The second mistake is having no clear requirements. If there is no description of goals, structure, content expectations and integrations, the project constantly shifts: new wishes appear, deadlines slip, the budget grows and no one is really satisfied.

The third mistake is saving on the important and overpaying for the secondary. A lot of budget goes into complex animations while speed, responsiveness, SEO and analytics are ignored. Or the cheapest option is chosen, which is almost impossible to scale properly later.

To avoid these problems, at the start you should: clearly define the goals of the site, outline a minimal page structure, list key integrations (payments, CRM, forms) and separate "must have" from "nice to have". This gives a predictable scope and a realistic result.

If you want to go through the website ordering stage without chaos and unnecessary costs, the easiest way is to request a consultation. I will help you create a solid brief, choose the right tech stack and focus on what really affects results: speed, SEO and user experience.
